cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: It is with sincere regret that we loam that "the eternal question of finance" is seriously handicapping the work of the Egypt Explora tion Fund. At the last ordinary general meeting of the Fund the treasurer presented » tfctemsut which he sorrowfully described as

"tho most unfavorable he hadhad to deal with.'' A deficit of £1,803 tor the last year is & serious oue. The decline of iu6bme has been caused by (o) the withdrawal of a great deal of support fwhn America—our American cousins are ^new uudertakiug independent investigation on their own aooount; (b) the increased success of the operations orgauised by the Fuud, which has necessitated additional expeditious, that have naturally involved increased expenditure, to the south of the great temple of Queen Hatshep.su t at Deir el-Bahari— a site of very great promise both historicaliy and archse dogioally. The work is only halffinished, and the Fund is under an engagement with the Egyptian authorities to complete the excavation and effect a clearance of the site. The prosideut of the fuud, Sir John EvauH,aud the hon. treasurer, H. A. Grueber, E»q., F.S.A, have issued a letter to subscribers to the Fund appealing tor increased support. We note in the letter that the ordinary subscription of one guinea, after deductingexpeuse* of publications annually distributed to cacll subociLer, etc., only leaves the small margin oi 3s. to be devoted to labour and other outlay in excavations. Magnificent opportunities for discoveries of immense interest and importance await the skilful labourer in this fas-iuatmg field. Alas I the work is terribly hampered by the tiuanoial difficulties which Lave overtaken it We venture to plead for a more generous measure of support of the Fund among Britishers resident iu Egypt, and now that our position here is more firmly established, the Egyptian Exploration Fuud may be said to have an additional claim on our attention and generosity.

A mob of strikers, enraged at the refusal of the manufacturers to payout more wages, until work is resumed, assembled outside a factory demanding money. The strikers began firiug at the troops from the windows of adjoining houses. The troops then fired into the crowd, and it is estimated that 20 persons were killed and 50 wouuded. A lew were wounded during encounters at other factories. (Reuter.)

The Russian Ironmasters have memorialised M. Witte demanding an improvement in the conditions of the workmen, tho equality of all iu the eyes of the law, the right for the workmen and masters alike to oease work, freedom of speech and press, and universal compulsory education. (Reuter.)

Anxiety here is again increasing. Five factories in the Viborg quarter are endeavouring to organise a general strike until a^l demands are satisfied. The authorities have requisitioned mounted grenadiers and dragoons frobi Peterhof. (Reuttr.)
A general strike has been resumed here.
(Reuter.)
The strikes are being ^resumed. Tliere are 16,000 strikers in the city, but they are keeping quiet The garrison has been reinforoed.
Some collisions have taken place at Lodz and Sosnowice, there being numerous victims.

A decree of the Tsar orders the formation of a committee to ascertain the causes of the workmeu's discontent and to devise measures for preventing the same in the future,
The committee consists of representatives of the Government Departments concerned, as well as representatives of industries and workmen. ( Reuter.)
The fears of renewed disturbances here today proved to be unfounded. The day passed quietly, the strikers being overawed by tho imposing display of military force.
'The situation in Polaud is still serious. 100,000 workmen remuiu on strike at L>dz, and fresh troubles are apprehended at Warsaw.

Contrary to expectations, complete calm prevailed to-day in the streets and factories.

div.head: KHARTOUM AGRICULTURAL EXHIBITION. VISITED BY DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: T.R.H. the Dake and Duchess of Connaught with the Princesses, accompanied by H.E. the Governor General, Lady Wingate, Col. Stanton, and other persounges, visited the annual Agricultural and Industrial Show this afternoon. There was a large concourse of people on the grounds at the time, and the excellent band of the Rifie Brigade discoursed sweet music.

Tieru sai vat few exhibits which deserve special mention this year. All the table decorations showed much taste. The O.M.8. girls' school made a debut in beautiful embroidery work in drawn thread and lacework. Next to that St. Anne's Catholic School made a nice show of similar and more elaborate needlework. The native embroidery was better than last year's display. For Sudav-growu ootton Mr. A. H. Capats received the first prize. The cotton from Mr. Grieve's Fadlab estate was also fair,
The Prisons are again good at furniture, and | especially lounge chairs. The vegetables gene

rally are more profuse than hitherto. The Steuners and Boats Department are, as usual, to the fond; thcir exhibit included a beautiful telucca made entirely of Bahr-et-Ghazal wood, I just the sort of boat one would like to possess.

Quartermaster Aliport, of the Rifle Brigade, expued a sinoker's companion made in brass from Boer shielis and rounds, which was very creditable. The consensus of opiuion, however, Jis that the exhibits weru poor and below those

of lust year. | Apparently the natives do not find sufficient inducement for them to show. Perhaps this ditficulty could be overcome by the enrolment of a working committee of civilians in addition to the official one. There is certain to be found | an aidvantage in enlisting the cu-operation of
competent business men. Popular têtes might I be included in the programme, also a weekly
fair as an encouraging adjauct. "Autres pays autros mous"

div.head: CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: The exhibits of Messrs. Steinemann, Mabar. di & Co, at the Vairo Agricultural Show are especiaily interesting, and include the following novelties, which are on show in Cairo for the first time :

Compound traction engine of 10 H.P.N. equal to about 55 H.P.I. This engine could be used for either of the following purposes :-for la 7 tine cunisator ; for a balance plough of 6 | shares (of which 3 shares zu frout and 3 shares behtad) for the "Elevating grade, wagor Loafer and ditcher," for cultivating purposes ; this machine is used for levellwg luud by removing the higher parts to a distance of 8 metres eituer un dilcies or into Wagous, eto. Be ides for cuilivating purpuses, the engine can be use i tur irrigation and for milling.
Kassabia which could be drawn by two pairs of uxen or by a suall truotion engine.
Kassabia ou wheels of various sizes which could be drawn by one pair of oxen.
Several Kassabia, Egyptian type, but the plates are made of steel instead of in wood, patent system,
Thrustning machine of smallest size made up-to-date, capable of threshing and bruising! 30 ardebs per day, and cutting the straw at the same tune to an extraordinary fineness.
Cieausing and grmling machine for wheat, clover, eto., vt special type.
All this machinery is to be at work at the exhibition, and one can judge and appreciate its work and utility.

Among the other exhibits of this Alexanorian engineering tiri are the following :Several portable engines of Messrs. Claytou & Shuttiuwurth's make for various purposes, viz: irrigation, inilling, threshing ; several centrifugal pumps of Messrs. Clayton & Shuttle! wortli's anaku and of Messrs. L. Dumont & Co.'s make ; maize shellers ; beau and oil cake mills ; Norwegian harrows ; crosskills ; mowing and reaping machines of Walter A. Wood's make ; and large assortineut of small materal esseutial to the agriculturist.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON AND THE COMBINE.
div.p: The amalgamation of the Federation of Master Cotton Spinuers and the Bolton Master Cotton Spinners' Association is looked upon in Lancashire as one of the most important steps which has been taken in recent years to unite the cotton industry. The Federation was initiated and carried out by Mr. C. W. Macara. But it comprised only the majority of the spinners of ordinary Americau cottous; the spinners of the finest American and of the fine Egyptian cottons, though organised, did not work with the Federation on the same lines. Last year the spinners of Egyptian cotton did | not join in the general short-time movement, and continued full production until circumstances proved too strong for them, | Egyptian cotton spinning is, it is said, the only part of the Lancashire trade which has done badly of late, yet of some twenty-six new spinning mills which are being erected, by far the greater number are intended for that class of work.

Lancashire tends to produce more and more of the finer and more costly cotton goods, and the Bolton Association, which is chiefly engaged in this department, will prove a powerful recroit to the Spinners' Federation. The latter body now controls over 30,000,000 spindles out of the 45,000,000 or 46,000,000 spindles which is England's share of the world's 110,000,000 spindles. ("Liverpool Journal of Commerce"))

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
MR. ALDERSON'S RESIGNATIONS.
div.p: The announcement of Mr. Geo. B. Alderson's resignation of his seat on the Alexandria Municipality came 88 a surprise to the many supporters of the "people's man." Mr. Alderson's | high character and position, and the public | spirit which animates all his actions, inspired universal respect and esteem among all classes of the community, and when he was elected not twelve months ago it was felt that the Municipality would be reinvigorated by his energy and influence.
It is expected that Mr. Alderson will be | asked to reconsider his decision to retire from
the ranks of the City Fathers, and it is to be | hoped that he will be induced to withdraw his resignation.

Referring to Mr. Alderspa's allegations, a member of the Municipal Delegation informs ne that, lar from what a correspondent writes | in our issue of Saturday last, to the effeqt that no notice had been taken of the letter from Mr. Alderson in the "Gazette" of Tuesday last, Mr. Ralli, as President of the Delegation, had T at the last plenary meeting protested strongly in the name of the Delegation that the contenta of the letter were quite contrary to the facts. Mr. Ralli recoguised that probably Mr. Alderson did not understand the import of what he wrote, but in saying that the "procès-verbaux" of the Delegation were "cooked" he simply attacked the honor of his colleagues. Mr.Alderson at once apologised for what he had written, stating that he had had no intention of attacking the honor of his colleagues. | Out of consideration for Mr. Alderson, nothing was put in the official report of the proceedings of the Commission, but it will appear in the regular minutes of the Municipal meetings.

div.head: THE TENANTS COMMISSION.
div.p: Mr. Geo. B. Alderson, honorary president of the Tenants Commission of Alexandria, has resigned his post ou that body on the ground that as the Societa Anonima di Case Economiche is on the point of formation he considers that his task is now at an end, the object for which he accepted the position having been accomplished.
Mr. Alderson has also resigned the honorary presidency of the Societa Margherita of Alexandria.
The following letter has been addressed by the Teuants' Commission to the capitalists who have interested themselves in the matter:--

" III:mo Signore, -Ho l'onore, a nome della Commissione che presiede, d'informare la 8. V., che essendosi il Sig. G. B. Alderson forma lizzato perchè questa Commissione era venuta a richiedere il di lei Coucorso finanziario per & Oustruzione di Oase Evonomiche, credette atale di ritirarsi, e questa Commissione apprezzando altamente il di loi valido appoggio, ha accettato le sue dimissioni da Presidente Onorario. Nell'attesa di comunicare al pubbliou il risultato della di lei munificenzs, ho l'onore di presentarle i miei inigliori omaggi.
Il Presidente, L. Ronci.

div.head: THE COOPER STEAM DIGGER. TRIALS AT SHOUBRA.
div.p: Very interesting trials of the Cooper Steam Digger were held on Boghos Pasha Nubar'sland at Shoubra on Saturday afternoon. A large number of agricultural experts and numerous members of the press were present at the trials, which were made under the supervision of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Sons, who are the agents in Egypt for the invention. The machine resembles a traction engine, carried on broad wheels, the front having a width of 24 in., the hind pair of 15 in. The digging gear consist of two pairs of two-pronged steel forks attached to driving shafts revolving on each side of a wheel carried behind. These forks can dig toadepth of 9 inches (maximum), the amount of penetration being regulated by adjusting the shoes. A fly-wheel is provided for driving an ordinary threshing machine, and the engine could also be used for stationary work, pumping, etc., and as a traction engine. The price of these engines, of which three bave been boughtby the Chaba and two by the Behera Land Company, is about £1,100, their coal consumption is from 1 to 1 kantar of coal an hour, and they can cover 7 feddans of ground a day. The width of the strips dug by the Cooper digger was 5 or 6 times greater than that of an ordinary hand plough, and the ease with which the machine turns and gets over rough ground must make it of great value.

During Saturday's trials the opinion was expressed that the digger would be most use ful in breaking up hravy unreclaimed land for the purpose of washing, and that it would be of great use on large estates. Its cost would, it was thought, be too great for it to used by small landowners. There was also some discussion as to whether the digging was quite deep enough, there being a minority who were not quite satisfied on this point. It was adınitted that the speed and bandiness of the digger were most important assets, and all present remarked that it broke the soil very thoroughly.

After the trials had been finished, those who had been invited by Messrs. Cook and Son partook of light refreshments in a large tent that had been erected on the ground, and returned to Cairo by a "special" after a moet interesting afternoon.

div.head: SHIP ON FIRE AT ALEXANDRPA.
div.p: Yesterday morning, at 2.0'elook, fire broke out on the S.S. "Antwerp City," in Alexandria harbour, and was not extinguished until: this morning.

The portion of cargo damaged consista, of about 600 tons of beans and 500 bales of cotton, but a large part of this will be saved. The total cargo consisted of 2,500 bales of cotton and some beans, cotton seed. eto.. | The steamer has been beached, but will be floated probably to-day. She was bonnd, for Havre and Dunkirk.
The origin of the fire is as yet unknown.

div.head: A BIG TROOPSHIP.
div.p: The new Royal Indian Marine troopship Dufferin," reached Port Said, at midday on Wed. Desday, outward bound for Bombay, where she will be taken over by the Indian Government, her present crew having been shipped only for the run out. She was built at Barrow-in-Furness at the naval construction works of Messrs. Viokers, Sons, and Maxim. It is claimed for the "Dufferin" that she is the largest ship of her class afloat-she has accommodation for almost 1,500. Designed by Sir Edward J. Reed, the consulting naval architect for the Indian Government, the vessel has a length between perpendiculars of 487 ft., a beam of 52.6 ft., and displaces 7,340 tons when drawing 19 ft. She is 80 ft. longer than her immediate predecessor, the "Hardinge," andisofcorrespondingly greater displacement. The contract was for a speed of 18.5 knots-on thesixtrial runs over the measur. ed mile she did 18.9, nearly : a mile more. The "Dufferin" has been designed with due consideration to her adoption as an armoured cruiser, and will be provided with eight 4.7 inch, and eight 3-pounder quick-firing guns, the largest size of searchlight projector, 8 large magazine and armoury under the water line, and other similar auxiliaries. Great care has been taken to ensure the vessel against sinking should she be in danger. There is a cellular double bottom, within which may be carried 800 tons of fresh water, and there are distillers for making 35 tons per day. Under the main deck tue vessel is sub-divided into a large number of water tight compartments, i the water-tight doors into which, for the first time in a troopship, are fitted with the Stone Lloyd system, by means of which all the doors can be closed in a few seconda by hydraulic gear worked from the captain's bridge. The "Dufferin" is double funnelled and has two pole masts with a straight stem and an eliptical stern. She will probably reach Bombay about the 18th inst.

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION
div.p: Dr. Budge has arrived in the Sudan to continue his important work there, this being ! his third campaign in that region. In his first expedition, shortly after the fall of Khartoum, he could, owing to the disturbed state of the country, do little more than make a reconnaissance for future work, and in the following yeat he made extensive explorations upon the pyramid fields of Meroe and Nursi, and was able from astronomical observations to Assign to them a date considerably older than was hitherto imagined. He also made excava tions upon the City of Napata— the site of which is situated below the cliffs of Jebel Barkal — and sufficient information was obtained to show that explorations upon the site would probably produce important results. It is to carry these out that he has now made a third expedition to the Sudan.

Mr. H. R. Hall is engaged with Prof. Nsyille in exploring the ancient temple of Mentahotep, of the Eleventh Egyptian dynasty, found beside the great temple at Deir el-Bahari, at Thebes. This is a most important work, for it proves that the terraced temple erected by Queen Hatshepsu was no foreign innovation, bat an enlarged and richer copy of the oldest temple at Thebes.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.
div.p: —We would call the attention of persons interested ir Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &o, to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £l and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-strest E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Our Luxor Correspondent writes that the Duke of Devonshire arrived there on Saturday on the dahabieh Hathor. His Grace paid a visit to the British consular agent, and was expected to stay at Luxor for a few days.
Lord and Lady Armstrong are coming to Egypt shortly.
Count Batthyany, the greats Hungarian magnate, who was in Cairo last winter, has again arrived at the Savoy.
Sir Ermest Cassel is going to stay on in Egypt for some time yet. Sir Renast is entertaining a great deal.
Sir Edward and Lady Colabponke are probably leaving the party, next Tuesday for Assouan, as also is Mr. Ward, who is likewise one of Sir Ernest's party.

Sir Ernest had a party to dinner at the Savoy restaurant yesterday, evening, the guests including : Sir Blwin and Lady Palmer, Mr. Vincent Corbet, Lord and Lady Londoeborough, Fabricing Pasha and Mme. Fabricing, Sir Edward Colekrooke, Countess Bosdari, Hon. Sidney Peel, Lord George Choimondeley, and Mrs. - Forester.
Lord and Lady Dalhousie also had a party to dinner at the Savoy restaurant yesterday evening, the guesta including the Hon, and Mrs. 0. Liridley, and Capt the Hon. A. F. Stanlay.
Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin entertained Izzet Pasha and Count Kodziebrodzki to dinner at the Savoy restaurant yesterday evening.
Crooksbank Pasha left Ahabuan on Saturday on board the Steamer "Pelicen" for Motana and Krmente.
Mr. William Copper, . director of the African Association, has arrived at Port Said. by the Bibby liner "Staffordabire,"

div.head: OBITUARY. EDWARD J. MANUK
div.p: We deeply regret to record the death, which occurred at his residence in Cairo yastarday, from heart failure," of Mr. Edward J. Manuk, one of the leading members of the Maltese colony in Egypt. Deceased, who was aged 63 years, had lived in Cairo for many years, and was a prominent figure in British scoial ciroles. His funeral will take place this afternoon at 3 o'clock. We beg to tander our sincera symapathy with deodaised's widow and his brother, Mr. B. 0, Manuk, of Alexandria

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
L'Imbroglio du Mariout
div.p: Ahmed Bey Izzy et consorts sont proprié tairas au Mariout. Bien qu'ils aient entre le-* mains de justes titres délivrés par le Gouvernement, ils se sont vus spoliés par les sieurs Abdel Hamid Soliman et consorts et ont dû intenter contre ces derniers une action nu pétitoire pour se faire réintégrer dans lcif légitime propriété.

Los spoliateursontdemandé àfaire l'éternelie prouve " que depuis plus do 15 ans ils ont d-* " lieux litigieux une possession paisible, publ " que, continue et non interrompue à titre non "équivoque de ,propriétaires, possession que " leurs auteurs avaient manifesté en se fixant " sur les terrains litigieux, en faisant régulière " ment et annuellement les cultures adaptées " en louant ou donnant en amodiation tout o i " partie do3 dits terrains, en y creusant de* " puits et en y établissant môme leur cimetière " de famille. ''

Notons d'abord qu'il 11 existe pas chez le* bédouins d'état civil pour permettre identifier les tombeaux et que le* puits creusés dans la localité remontent la plupart ou temps des premiers khédives et quelques-uns d'outre eux à l'époque de la conquête romaine.

Nous avons d'ailleurs dit déjà ce qu'il fallait penser d'une descente sur les lieux au Mariout et de la valeur des témoignages que peuvent fournir des nomades voués à la rapine et nu brigandage. Aussi ne reviendrons-nous pas sur cette question. Nous nous contenterons «le reproduire un arrêt do la Cour rendu en 1892 dans une cause identique à celles du Mariout et qui mit fin d'un seul coup à toutes les usurpations du même gonre.

Cet arrêt définit en tonnes précis la façon d'établir la prescription légale. "Lorsqu'il " s'agit, dit-il, d'un terrain vague, inculte, sans " arrosage et dépourvu do toute habitation,,il " faut prévenir par la construction de bornes " en maçonnerie parfaitement apparente*, par " l'établissement d'un jardin, l'ensemencement " annuel à la saison des pluies et la plantation " même momentanéed uue clêiture de figuessau- " vagespour avertir le propriétairequesourdrait " est en danger d'être proscrit" (affaira Nicola D. G. Josich contre Joseph Suarès et Cie.)

En appliquant cette.décision au Mariout on mettrait fin à la plupart des procès (pii^sissent dans cette région de ce que les noufàdis prétendent y faire ucte de possession sirr dos milliers de feddans par le simple établissement d'une tente et l'ensemencement de quelques morceaux de terrain.

Avant l'institution des tribunaux de la Ré forme, le Gouvernement disposait de ses biens libres comme il l'entendait. Personne no cherchait h lui en disputer la propriété. Los terrains de Randeh, habités par dos bédouins, furent concédés à des particuliers par l'Etat Bans qu'aucuno difficulté ne surgit.

C'est que la "prescription" n'avait pas encore été importée en Egypte. Elle y vint en 1X76 avec la promulgation des "Codes Mixtes" calqués sur les "Codes Français". Profitant do cette aubaine, les tripoteurs d'affaires, (il y en a dans tous les pays), rompus aux subtilités de la Loi, ne manquèrent pas d'engager des ac tions contre le Gouvernement en lui réclamant dos terrains prétendument prescrits. Les pre mières affaires réussirent, mais coiiMaa le nombre de* spéculateurs allait en augmentant, la Justice se ravisa et se moutra par la suite plus circonspecte à admettre de pareilles prétentions. Ces sortes d'entreprises durèrent jusqu'au jour oh fut rendu l'arrêt mémorable dont nous avons reproduit un extrait. Cette date marque une nouvelle ère de prospérité et de paix pour les localités sises aux alentours de Rnmleh : Mandara, Siouf, Kharabet, etc.

Le mouvementspéculatif, qui avait pour base la prescription et pourobjctles terrains du Gouvernement ou dessesconcessionnaires, cessa virtuellement d'exister dès cette époque. Il no se réveilla qu'en 1900 à la nouvelle do l'irrigation du Mariout par le Canal Nubarieh. L'élan et les proportions furent telles cette fois qu'on se demaude quand et comment la justice pourra sortir de cet imbroglio. Elle ne le pourra jamais si elle persiste dans le système actuellement en vigueur, qui est long, embarrassant et fort ooftteux. L'arrêt du 24 novembre 1904 pur lequel la Cour rejetait l'offre d'une preuve illusoire, faite avec des éléments suspects, avait bien un moment fait espérer que la procédure ainsi raccourcie aurait réglé le tas d'affaires en Suspens et assuré par là même au Mariout un peu d'ordre et de sécurité. Mais il n'en est rien malheureusement. Il semble par les enquêtes qu'on ordonne de nouveau (comme dans l'affairo Izzi dont il est question ci-dessus) qu'on veuille retourner aux premiers errements qui out engendré I imbroglio actuel.

Toute cette question du Mariout est pourtant bien simple. Eile se résume en ceci : La région du Mariout est déserte. A l'exception de l'ezbet Parisi-Malouk et des stations de S.A. le Khédive il u'existe pas la moindre exploitation foncière. Les bédouins vivant sous des tentes qu'ils déplacent à tout instant ne peuvent prétendre à la possession ni à la prescription. Celle ci d'ailleurs leur a été déniée dès l'origine par les rescrits de.? khédives qui réservent à l'Eta^ la propriété de toute la région qui borde le dése'rt lybiquc. En faisant mémo abstraction de ces rescrits, la prescription et la possession ne peuvent exister en droit chez les nomades en l'absence de toute culture régulière, de toute construction et de toute population sédentaire. L'admission do ce principe trancherait toutes les difficultés.

Toute somme ajô&t le paiement est retardé portera de pleiudroit intérêts en faveur de la Société au taux de 7 % l'an, à compter du jour de l'exigibilité, sons aucune demande en justice. (Art. 7 des Statute). 35488-8*-!

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
( Communication Officielle. )
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 11 lévrier 1905 à 4 h. p.m. sous la présidence <lo M. Auib. A. Ralii.
Présents : MM. Fender], Abani Bey, Man- sour Bey Youssef, Stress, Dr G. Valensiu, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrate! r, A. Wilner, secrétaire p. i.

La Délégation renvoie à l'examen du Comité des Travaux publics une proposition des services techniques tendant à l'exécution «Mboi - tains travaux pour la protection du collecteur général, à Kaït Bey, près du fort.

Elle proposera à la Commission les crédits nécessaires pour la irecouatruction à l'alignement nouveau, par suite de la transformation en parc île la façade de l'hôpital du Gouverne ment, du mur de clôture de cet établissement.

Sur rapport du Comité dos Travaux Publics, la Délégation adjuge à M. P. Uerakis les travaux de construction d'un tronçon du collecteur Est ainsi que de sou raccordement à l'égout de la rue do la Porte Rosette, au prix de L.E. 7,600.
Les travaux d empierremeut de la rue do Ras-el-Tin, depuis le dallage actuel jusqu'à l'entrée du Palais, sont adjugés à M.V. di Bari.

Communication est donnée d'une lettre de Ç.E. le Ministre de l lutérieur informant que le règlement sur la rage élaboré par le Gouvernement sera prêt dans quelques jours et que la Municipalité sera libre de le mettre en ap plication immédiatement à Alexandrie par arrêté municipal. Cette lettre sera soumise à la Commissiou Municipale, dont la prochaine séance est fixée au 22 lévrior 1905.
La séance est levée à 7 h. p.m.

div.head: SERVICE DES RECETTES
AVIS
div.p: Messieurs les Propriétaires d'immeubles bâtis à Alexandrie et dans sa banlieue, sont informés que, en exécution de l'article 11 du décret du

Mars 1884, les rôles d'imposition pour l'exercice 1905 dressés on vertu et en conformité des décrets du 13 Mars 1884 et 11 Avril 1886, ont été arrêtés et rendus exécutoires à partir du 10 Février 1905.

Les rôles d'imposition comprennent les constructions imposées en 1887 et dont les huit années sont révolues ainsi que celles nouvellement coustruites et achevées en 1904 ; ces rôles sont déposés à la Municipalité au Service des Recettes, oii les propriétaires pourront on prendre connaissance.
Les rôles d'imposition sont mis en recouvrement et chaque contribuable doit payer le montant de l'impôt dont il est redevable, sous peine d'y être coutraiut, en conformité de l'art.
du décret du 13 Mars 1884.

L'impôt est payable par trimestre d'avance contre des reçus émanant du Service des Recettes, portant le cachet du Directeur du Service et la signature du percepteur chargé du recensement pour chaque immeuble séparémout.

Les réclamations à formuler devant le Conseil do révision contre les opérations de recensement devront être présentées jusqu'au 10 Mai 1905 pour les propriétés dont les huit ans sont révolus, et 10 Août 1905 pour les constructions nouvelles.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie le 8 Février 1905. 25437-3-1

div.head: SOURSE KHEDIVIALE
Remarques sur le marché du disponible et contrats.
div.p: Disponible.—La soinaino avait commencé avec une assez bonne demande et une tendance plutôt favorable, mais sur la continuation de la baisse en Amérique, il y a eu revirement et la finale a été calme avec un certain arrêt dans les transactions. Toutefois, comme prix, nous avons gagné de 1/4 à 3/8 de talari, sur presque tous les classements, l'Abassi excepté.
Franoo-gare.—Il n'y a ou que peu d'affaires, l'Intérieur ayant été moins facile à la détente.

Contrats.—Nouvelle récolte. La nouvelle réoolte profite par ricochet de l'activité et des fluctuations do l'anciennce, mais au foud la faveur de la spéculation ne s'y porte que par intermittence. En résumé, ello est ferme et il y a un nouveau rapprochement entre les cours.

Récolte actuelle. La récolte actuelle, ferme au commencement de la semaine, avait fini par 8q ressentir de la baisse de l'Américain et cela d'autant plus que quelques intéressés à la hausse avaient liquidé ou allégé leurs positions ; depuis hier soir, cependant, il y a de nouveau revirement et la clôture d'aujourd'hui a été très bonne, surtout pour le mars, dont le découvert commence à s'inquiéter. *'£,
Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour mars tal. 12 9,16 à —/—; plus bai pour mars 12 1/4 à —/—.
Graines de coton
Disponible.—11 n'y a rien de particulier à dire sur le disponible, dont les fluctuations out suivi celles des contrats, ce qui explique la hausse enregistrée.
Fruuco-gare.—Toujours la même nullité d'affaires.

Contrats.—Nouvelle récolte. On n'y fait que de rares affaires, mais tout naturellement ello a subi l'influence de la vieille récolte et, comme j résultat, il y a uno hausse assez marquée sur | les trois mois. Récolte actuelle.—Le début do la semaino ne s'annonçait nullement comme favorable, ! mais depuis trois jours la hausse a fait du ; chemiu, grâce à la première poussée donnée par la spéculation et à l'amélioration à Hull i motivée par dos achats spéculatifs.

div.head: THE NILE IN 1904.
(continued).
div.p: Lake Tsana is well described and a plan with much interesting information is given showing its outlet,
Chapter 3 deals at considerable length with the utilisation of the Nile, from which wo quote the following interesting passage on the peculiar phenomenon of the "green water."—

"The colour, of Nile water is generally a pale yellow, but in June, when the first indications of the coming Hood are given by a continuous gentle rise of the river from its minimum gauge, the water changes to gr»eu and run;.ins so for two or three week-. This green water has a very disagreeable taste ami odour, and is especially objectionable when the Nile has beeu very low and the rise is a slow one. in June 1900 it was extraordinarily bad, and the river water was so poor in oxygen that standing on Kasr el N d bridge at Cairo one Cut)Id see Hie suriace of the water covered with fi-li which apparently could only live near the surface, in ttie deep reaches near lvalabasha, in Nubia, the fish died in myriad.-,. Tins green water is attributed by some to the immense amount of vegetable matter brought down by the White Nile from the Sudd region, dome say that it comes principally with the first rise of the Sobat river. But tbo generally accepted theory to-day is that the green water is the result ol vegetable growths from germs in the water itself, and that wherever or whenever the current becomes exceedingly slack they multiply greatly. Upstream of the Assouan dam in June, 1903, the water was extraordiuarily green and exceedingly objectionable. As it was shot out ol the upper sluices of the dam and broken up into spray ou the downstream side of the dam it become so purified that I juuud it dilhcult to understand that the water flowing past Elephantine Island was what I had seen at Sbelial."

The author pays a tribute to the memory of the great hydraulic engineer Louibardini, who predicted many years ago that more careful gaugings would astonish engineers as to the amount of subsoil water which filters into the Nile, to be given buck to the river in the mouths of deflux ; he predicted that this would be found to counterbalance the heavy evaporation of April, May, and June, and receut research has substantiated his opinion.

The author sums up his opinion of basin irrigatiou as follows-': "Considering the times of flood and low supply, the climate of Egypt, the turbidity of the Nile Hood, and the. deltaic formation of the Nile Valley, no better system than basin irrigation as practised in Egyyt could possibly have beeu devised. If the flood had come in April and May and been followed by a burning summer, or if the actual autumn floods had been followed by the frozen winters of Europe or the warm winters of the Sudan, basin irrigation would have been a failure or a very moderate success; but, given the Egyptian climate, basin irrigation has stood without a rival for 7,000 years. Basin irrigation, as it has been practised in Egypt for thousands of years, is the most efficacious method of utilising existing meaus of irrigation which tbo world has witnessed. It can be started by the sparsest of populations. It will support in wealth a multitude of people. King Meues made his first dyke when the Egyptian nation was in its infancy. Egypt,in Homan times, supported a population twice as deuse as that of to-day. The direct labour of cultivation reduced to an absolute minimum......... Subsoil

water supplies the link between basin and perennial irrigatiou. It explains the reason why modem Egypt is not satisfied with the irriga tion which has come dowu from the remotest antiquity, but is desirous of conferring on the length and breadth of the Nile Valley those advantages which gave AbydoB, Memphis, and Thebes their pre eminence iu the past. Any country which possesses rivers and streams, whose waters are in flood for six weeks per annum at a suitable season of the year, can betake itself to basin irrigation with more or less profit. The science of dams, weirs and regulators has received such development during recent years that there can be no problem so difficult that it cannot be solved by experience and originality.

The subject of perennial irrigation is treated at length. With reference to this he says, "Some of ihe perennial cauuls are very capacious. The two largest discharge 700 and 450 cubic metres per second respectively. There are no artificial canals in the world like them. All the canals are liberally provided with regulators and locks. The energies of the Irrigation Department duriDg the last ten years have been chiefly directed to the provirion of sufficient drains to meet that over satu- idtion of the soil, which all but the best re gu'ated perennial irrigation invariably entails.
, After many years in India and Egypt, we am convinced that the construction of drains | and escapes should precede, and not follow,

!; canals. It seems fatuous for engineers to < be always over-saturating and half-ruining tens of thousands of acres of low lying lands, during the improvement of hundreds of thousands of actes of high-lying lands, when it would be prefectly easy, with a little foresight, to secure all tbo advautages without piling up disadvantages."

The author passes over in a few lines the important question of the period of inception of the Assouan dam and the studies which preceded its execution. As these are matters with which he was so intimately connected, we think that this is to be regretted. He says:

" 1 lie Assouan Reservoir at its present level contains one milliard of cubic metres of water which will sullice lor the conversion of halt a million acres perennial irrigation, uddmg £15,U<X),(XK) to the wealth of the country. But though the dam was only completed at the end of 1902, already the- whole of the water has been devoted to special tracts, and the Government is reluctantly compelled to refuse all applications lor water."

Lake Mœris and the Wadi Rayau project are well described iu several interesting pages, Irom which we extract the following few lines : "The connection between the Nile, and the germ of the future Lake Mœris was inexistence in King Menes's time, as I have been informed by Frolessor Sayce, but it was King Amenetn- but, of the Xllth dynasty, who widened and deepened the canal, cleared away the rocky barriers, and converted the trilling lake of King Jdeues's time into the mighty inland sea wnich controlled the highest floods of the Nile, -Those ancient Fharaulia wore giants iu hydraulic engiueenng. They were, moreover, as wise as they wore courageous."

W ith reference to the complete project for water storage and flood protection for Egypt, after giving many details the author says : "Tue great advantage of undertaking all those works together may he thus summarised. The increased supply torn the Assouau reservoir will be telt in Egypt after a period o! two years. Five years later tbo waters of the VV ady Rayau will he added to those of the Assouan reservoir, and it will be possible to increase the cotton crop of Egypt from 6 million to 10 million owt. It will be possible to allow the Sudan to thoroughly develop its agricultural resources, and with the aid of the • 25,DUO horse power us a minimum which the Gill cataract near Khartoum can supply, to utilise lor its own consumption the waters wnich cau be stored at that cataract ; and, iu addition to those, the available supplies from Lake Tsana provided that that lake is furnished with an outlet tunnel.'

Uu the developomeut of the Sudan the author has much to say which is of interest Chapter 5 describes the oases and geology of the Nile valley. As some of the oases are described at considérable length, we are surprised that uothiug should be said about the important fciwa oasis.

The book ^completed by 10 appendices containing much information referring to the Nile, and other tables lor lauililaliug calculations in connection with them; they are all very well arranged. We notice that the meteorological tables only comprise .three years ; this is too short a time to admit#!any general deductions oeing made from them, it is very probable that some of the southern stations have only recently been created, but those of Assouau, Cairo, and Alexandria could with great advantage have been given lor the last ten or fifteen years. We would venture to suggest that in a luture edition, it would be au advantage to state the rainfall separately, dividing it into seasons of autumn and winter, such divisions having much more connection with the Nile flood than has the calendar year.

Both to the general observer and to students of hydrology, wo * stroDgly recommend the study of this book ; even to the comparatively few, who have time and opportunity for the study of all that has been published on the N ile, it will be found valuable ; while to the larger number, who are glad to fiud within a small compass all they require to know, it will be of the greatest servico both as a book to read, and as au easy book of reference ; for it brings up to date, in a condensed form, and from many . sources, all the knowledge which has resulted from many years of patient study and research.

No doubt the author is correct in saying that the mystery of the Nile is far from being solved. Still it must be admitted that the Irrigation Department, of which ho was himself for many years a distinguished member, Las withiu the last twenty years done an immense deal in the way of scientific research, culminating withSir William Garstin's monumental report of last year on the basin of the Upper Nile. Its tributaries have been explored, the lakes at its head waters examined, their water sheds have beeu estimated and measured ; and even the effect on them of the monsoons of the great Indian Ocean has ireen taken into consideration. When all those elements shall have been further studied, and we have all the information that human skill and perseverance can give us, we shall still be in presence of the fact noted by a wise man, ages ago, that "the wind bloweth whore it "listeth and thou hearest the sound thereof, "but thou canst not tell whence it cometbe "nor whither it goeth," and so it probably will be with every human effort to determine the reasons which cause the variation in the floods of the Nile.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by out correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits—free discursion
MISSIONS TO MOHAMBDAN8.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazbttb.

Dear Sir,—I have read with astonishment your leading article in the "Egyptian Gazette" of 7th inst., on "Missions to Mohamedans," iD which yon conclude that Egypt's great need is not religion b»0 sanitation. 1 don't want to enter into a controversy with you, but would like to tell you in a few words my own experience as a Moslem. I was a strict follower of the religion of Islam and was educated thoroughly in all its precepts, and that in lands where no other religion is known or taught, the Hadramniit and the Yemen. Eventually I became Kadi ul Islam, and so zealous was I, that not only did I observe all that was imposed upon me by the Koran, but many things in addiiion, such as the pilgrimage to Medina, the opening of my house to all Moslem strau- gers, the spending of many of the nights of Ramadan iu prayer and reuding of the Koran, and the supplying of the wants of the poor to the utmoMt ot my ability. All that 1 did in order to find peace with God and rest for my soul, but the only result was increased fear and trouble of conscience, till 1 could find no pleasure in anything. 1 thought that this state must arise Irom our negieoting as Moslems ilie sacred duty imposed upon us by our religion, of waging war agaiust the unbelievers, and as 1 had not. the power to do that, I tried to make amends for it'by hating them with all my heart, till I could hardly bear the sight of a Christian. And so I remained without hope and without rest, until coming to Aden I met a friend who had a very different feqjing towards me and my felluw-Aloslems from wha> you have. Having tasted the joy and blessing ot a living saviour, he was auxious that ail the world should kuow him loo ; lor the Christian religion diflors from all the other religions in the world in this, that it consists in the knowledge of a person, a living person, and not in the holding uf dogmas and creeds. I le p eached to me Jesus, and 1 believed iu Him as my saviour and fourni peace. It meant that I lost everything, that iny uarne was defamed, my life attempted, and 1 became a poor outcast and wanderer from my native laud. Everybody forsook me, and 1 have beeu at times without bread to eat, but in the midst of it all my heart has been full of joy and luvo to God am* aR men, especially my own people.

' lam afraid, dear sir, Irom your article that you know not yet iu your heart the presence of this saviour, or you would have a better Gospel to preaiw than the Gospel of sanitation. Is it possible that I, the poor Moslem, have en ered into the Kingdom of Heaven before you the learned citizen of a Christian nation? even as He .aid of old to the Pharisees, "the publicans and harlots shall enter into the Kingdom of Heaven before you." —Yours sincerely,.
Salem El Khkmhy.
